awd_titl_txt: RCN: A community of ex situ microbial germplasm collections
awd_abstract_narration:
A network bringing together scientists working with laboratory based collections of microbes is being established. The network will hold numerous workshops teaching best practices for managing, preserving, and distributing bacteria, fungi, and other microscopic organisms in the context of formal culture collections. Biosecurity and regulatory issues will also be emphasized at workshops. Additional goals include re-establishing a professional society of culture collection researchers in the US, developing internet based collection management tools, and fostering communication between US collections, foreign collections, and international collection networks.

Collections of living microbes assure that current and past research and innovation are available to future generations of scientists. Biological materials which are made available via well managed collections represent the foundation of the modern biotechnology industry. Materials in culture collections impact fields as diverse as human health, agricultural productivity, biotechnology, and bio-diversity research.  While there are several professional collections in the US, most collections in the US are small and do not have long term strategies for survival. The network supported by this grant will ensure that smaller collections benefit from expertise available at larger living microbe collections.

por.por_cntn:
Project aims:

The major goals of this project are to provide venues for interaction of living microbe collection workers, to promote best practices, and to engage the national and international living collection community.

 

The Research Coordination Network for ex situ Microbial Germplasm Collections, U.S. Culture Collections Network (USCCN) was formalized in 2012 with sponsorship by the National Science Foundation (NSF). The mission statement as written in 2012 was “to facilitate the safe and responsible utilization of microbial resources for research, education, industry, medicine and agriculture for the betterment of humankind.” The original aims of the USCCN were:

  1. Organize workshops to address the challenges faced by culture collections
  2. Coordinate community efforts for cyberinfrastructure
  3. Develop a formal off-site preservation plan
  4. Fund visits by less experienced collection curators to successful culture collections to demonstrate best practices
  5. Strengthen contacts among US collections, and with international collections
  6. Explore mechanisms for long-term support of USCCN

 

Since 2012, USCCN has provided a unique venue for managers and curators of living and research-focused microbe collections to promote best practices and to engage the larger living collection community more broadly, both nationally and internationally. The organized platform afforded opportunities for U.S. culture collection workers to engage with each other and with the broader culture collection community worldwide. The structure allowed for rapid response to unanticipated issues such as the Nagoya protocol, and a disruptive proposed major change in the taxonomic code. Specific accomplishments of USCCN include:

  • USCCN held annual meetings covering various themes on issues such as use of specimens from collections in genome sequencing projects, the Nagoya Protocol, outreach programs, data standards, off-site cryopreserved backup services, and how to preserve endangered collections.
  • USCCN has also served as a sounding board for collection personnel to compare collection management practices such as databases, websites, international shipping challenges, and new products and services, most recently in the form of virtual meetings.
  • Meeting discussions led to 12 peer-reviewed publications and book chapters co-authored by USCCN participants.
  • Collection personnel have traveled to visit other U.S. collections and to international culture collection conferences.
  • Sixteen US microbial collections have cryopreserved off-site stocks at the USDA National Laboratory for Genetic Resource Preservation at Fort Collins, Colorado.
  • Five collections deposited their online catalogs in the Global Catalog of Microorganisms, making the collections more visible to international researchers.

 

USCCN has shaped life science behind the scenes. For example, in February 2020, the Network engaged with the International Committee on Systematics of Prokaryotes to discourage a disruptive proposal that would have allowed genome sequences to serve as type material. Passage of this proposal could have impacted all taxonomy including eukaryotes because intact organism specimens are preferred as nomenclatural type specimens across the tree of life. The Network submitted a response detailing the primarily negative impact of the proposed change and recommended that it not be approved. The International Committee on Systematics of Prokaryotes denied the proposed changes, in large part due to the input from USCCN.

 

In the summer of 2020, USCCN received permission to use its remaining 2012 grant funds to initiate an upgrade on its website www.usccn.org. These funds were originally targeted for meeting travel and in person workshops, which were stopped abruptly in March 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The website received a fresh new look with a new logo, color scheme and updated material provided by USCCN leadership and the communications committee. The site went live on December 1, 2020. Furthermore, preliminary work began on conceptualizing and developing an online registry and public database of all sizes and types of microbial culture collections, addressing one of the recommendations of the 2020 National Academies report. A list of collection registration questions was developed by the USCCN membership committee and improved by the broader USCCN community. In addition to learning about the size, type, and functions of each collection, questions were included that enable partnerships with other national and international organizations that also are interested in registering microbe culture collections. This registry has been beta-tested on a small scale.
